comments:
Not sure if AJDT is the right place for JFace bugs....
I can't tell why I'm getting what seems to be an internal error
to TableViewer (in the TableViewerImpl class.)
This could very well be my misusing TableViewer but if so,
shouldn't I get a more informative error message? i.e.
shouldn't TableViewerImpl be catching this error
and maybe throwing some kind of exception?

java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.jface.viewers.TableViewerImpl.activateCellEditor
(TableViewerImpl.java:61)
	at org.eclipse.jface.viewers.TableViewerImpl.activateCellEditor
(TableViewerImpl.java:134)
	at org.eclipse.jface.viewers.TableViewerImpl.handleMouseDown
(TableViewerImpl.java:231)
	at org.eclipse.jface.viewers.TableViewer$1.mouseDown
(TableViewer.java:320)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.TypedListener.handleEvent
(TypedListener.java:132)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java:82)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Widget.java:847)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runDeferredEvents(Display.java:2311)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:1992)

I'm getting the exact same thing while developing a standalone GUI app.  Same
stack trace as well.

This error occurs when TableViewer.setColumnProperties(String[] sa) is called.
I'm not sure why this needs to be here, but these are needed when methods on the
ICellModifier is called.

Maybe these should be generated internally as each column is added?

Is this still a problem in Eclipse 3.0 final? Can you provide a testcase? If the
problem is not specific to AJDT, we can move the bug on to the relevant component.
Thanks Paul. That's quite an old version, 3.0M6. Is it still a problem in 3.0 final?

I guess I will have to download 3.0 final and upgrade and get back to you. As a 
working note, I've found that occasionally when you don't get a very 
informative error/stack trace etc., one approach is to put smaller try/catch 
statements around code snippets, to catch generic exception classes. This will 
sometimes show you the specific area where you may have a null data value or 
something. It's generally considered poor practice to catch generic errors and 
act on them but for debugging puporses it seems to be a handy trick.

Assuming this is no longer an issue. If it turns out it is, please raise a jface
bug.
